table-wrap.anchoringText: Water Breakthrough happened in the P1 well within six months of bringing the well on stream (Figure 4) and the water cut (WC) increased sharply to 50% within a few weeks. An interference test was conducted between the P1 and W1 wells to check for hydraulic connectivity. However, the pressure pulse from the W1 well did not reach the producer even after 2 days of monitoring, against the expected 1.3 days of transmission lag time based on theoretical calculations. Also, the composition analysis on water samples (Table 1) taken from the P1 well, showed that the produced water properties (salinity) are more consistent with the formation water than with the injected seawater.
table-wrap.label: Table 1
table-wrap.caption: Comparison of results from chemical analysis of produced water from P1 well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of results from chemical analysis of produced water from P1 well

table-wrap.anchoringText: It was inferred that because of the below tuning nature of the seismic and the presence of the aquifer, the reservoir amplitude in the area between the producer well and the aquifer in the East is not representative of the actual net sand distribution. Hence it was decided to carry out manual facies updates in this area based on conceptual models in an iterative manner till reasonable history match is achieved (described in Table 2 and Figure 6). Each realization yielded incrementally better history-matches (in terms of WBT & WC) than previous iteration. Iteration 6 had a better injector performance match, which was obtained by introducing flow barriers (Ibrahimov, 2015) between the producer and injector (Figure 7).
table-wrap.label: Table 2
table-wrap.caption: Iteration 1 to Iteration 6 Facies Update Description

formatted-caption.caption-text: Iteration 1 to Iteration 6 Facies Update Description
